column9:
Agenda


tags$strong(tags$em('Start by doing what is necessary; then do what is possible; and suddenly you are doing the impossible.'))

 ~ Francis of Assisi

Lesson: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1XFU8nEpnvoJKES4SxO88L3ddqAtZtQTeEauLzQlFfXk/edit?usp=sharing

Repository: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-WelcomeR

Download Repository: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-BestScripting/archive/main.zip

Open R Studio and check it out: 

1. R project

2. Keyboard shortcuts (Tools > Keyboard shortcuts)

3. Workflow (good file structure)- example

4. Basic math

5. Vectors, Matrices, Arrays, Lists, and Data Frames

6. Best Practices Review

Resources

From the presentation:

1. Our Coding Club: https://ourcodingclub.github.io/tutorials.html

2. Wilson et al., 2017: Good enough practices in scientific computing: https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1005510

3. Math functions in R (resource): https://www.guru99.com/r-functions-programming.html

4. Data Types in R: https://www.programcreek.com/2014/01/vector-array-list-and-data-frame-in-r/

Other great resources: 

1. [Textbook] Intro to R for Data Science (Hadley Wickham): https://r4ds.had.co.nz/index.html

2. [Textbook] Advanced R (Hadley Wickham): https://adv-r.hadley.nz/

3. R Cheatsheets: https://rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/

4. Jenny Bryan: what they forgot to teach you about R: https://rstats.wtf/index.html 

5. Interactive Learning in R: https://swirlstats.com/students.html 

6. Eric Dunford’s Intro to R course & slides: http://ericdunford.com/ppol670/ 

7. Our Coding Club: https://ourcodingclub.github.io/tutorials.html 

8. Swirl R Package: https://swirlstats.com/students.html

An informal opprotunity to come by to ask any questions you have about the course, content, or with specific questions about issues you have with the homework or in your own analyses.

Today's Homework

1. Practice the skills we just learned in R! Download and refer to 9_homework1.R: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-WelcomeR/blob/main/R/9_homework1.R

2. Add to Share Insights with one thing you learned!: https://emilymarkowitz-noaa.github.io/FishR101/share-help.html

Welcome! 

Answers to the homework will be added here.

Agenda

tags$em('You can not use #tidyverse without base R. It is not a dichotomy. Pick the tools that make you most effective.')

 ~ The Great Hadley Wickham, creater of Tidyverse

Lesson: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1C855dzCUu25-45f4rLHJc56hkBTS309JC_cNRa_lItM/edit?usp=sharing

Reprository: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-BaseRvTidy

Download Repository: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-BaseRvTidy/archive/main.zip

0. Review of how to create R Projects and download content from GitHub: https://docs.google.com/document/d/17vqfBYUxyasruIdkjhp2YA3Afcr1BXvcSoQ5lvl3Wcs/edit?usp=sharing
1. The importance of checking as you go.  ; 

2. Loading libraries (e.g. tidyverse: install.packages() and library())

3. Best practices - ‘renv’ package to track package versions in projects

*Note that after this lessson we will be focusing on Tidy methods.

Resources

1. R Project: https://www.r-project.org/about.html


2. The Comprehensive R Archive Network: CRAN and all the packages


3. Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/ 


4. janitor package (e.g., clean_names()): https://garthtarr.github.io/meatR/janitor.html#clean_names() 


5. renv package: https://rstudio.github.io/renv/articles/renv.html 


6. EXTRA: R Cheatsheets: https://rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/

Inspiration Time!


You Should Learn to Program: Christian Genco at TEDxSMU: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xfBWk4nw440

An informal opprotunity to come by to ask any questions you have about the course, content, or with specific questions about issues you have with the homework or in your own analyses.

Today's Homework

1. Practice the skills we just learned in R! Download 3_homework.R

R Script of questions: https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-BaseRvTidy/blob/main/code/3_homework.R


Pretty PDF of questions (made in R Markdown): https://github.com/EmilyMarkowitz-NOAA/FishR101-BaseRvTidy/blob/main/code/3_Homework.pdf


2. Add to Share Insights with one thing you learned! 

Add to the google docs how you will be able to use what you learned today to improve how you work with data: https://emilymarkowitz-noaa.github.io/FishR101/share-help.html


3. Check out the rstudio global(2021): https://rstudio.com/conference/

Check out any of the talks, but the first keynote talk by Hadley Wickham might be a good one!: https://global.rstudio.com/student/page/40521?course_session_id=2792
